DataElement.preferredName: Bile Duct Cancer Primary Risk Factor Name
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term to represent the name of the primary condition that increases a person's chance of developing a malignant tumor of the bile duct.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Bile Duct Carcinoma Primary Risk Factor
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A malignant tumor arising from the epithelium of the intrahepatic or extrahepatic bile duct.  Carcinomas that arise from the intrahepatic bile ducts and the hepatic ducts are called cholangiocarcinomas and are almost always adenocarcinomas.  Carcinomas that arise from the extrahepatic bile ducts are adenocarcinomas, adenosquamous carcinomas, squamous cell carcinomas, small cell carcinomas, or mucoepidermoid carcinomas._Occurring first in time or sequence; original; of greatest rank or importance or value._Any aspect of an individual's life, behavior, an environmental exposure, or an inborn or inherited characteristic that increases the likelihood of a disease, condition or injury.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A malignant tumor arising from the epithelium of the intrahepatic or extrahepatic bile duct.  Carcinomas that arise from the intrahepatic bile ducts and the hepatic ducts are called cholangiocarcinomas and are almost always adenocarcinomas.  Carcinomas that arise from the extrahepatic bile ducts are adenocarcinomas, adenosquamous carcinomas, squamous cell carcinomas, small cell carcinomas, or mucoepidermoid carcinomas.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from the intrahepatic or extrahepatic bile ducts.

Property.preferredDefinition: Occurring first in time or sequence; original; of greatest rank or importance or value.:Something that increases the chance of developing a disease. Some examples of risk factors for cancer are age, a family history of certain cancers, use of tobacco products, being exposed to radiation or certain chemicals, infection with certain viruses or bacteria, and certain genetic changes.

Concepts.definition: Occurring first in time or sequence; original; of greatest rank or importance or value.
Any aspect of an individual's life, behavior, an environmental exposure, or an inborn or inherited characteristic that increases the likelihood of a disease, condition or injury.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Created for HCC and Bile Duct Cancer CDE request 8.16.18 mc

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Occurring first in time or sequence; original. (American Heritage Dictionary)_Anything that increases a person's chance of developing a disease. Some examples of risk factors for cancer include a family history of cancer, use of tobacco products, certain foods, exposure to radiation or cancer-causing agents, and certain genetic alterations._The words or language units by which a thing is known.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A chronic, autoimmune inflammatory liver disorder characterized by narrowing and scarring of the lumen of the bile ducts. It is often seen in patients with ulcerative colitis. Signs and symptoms include jaundice, fatigue, and malabsorption. It may lead to cirrhosis and liver failure.

Concepts.definition: A chronic, autoimmune inflammatory liver disorder characterized by narrowing and scarring of the lumen of the bile ducts. It is often seen in patients with ulcerative colitis. Signs and symptoms include jaundice, fatigue, and malabsorption. It may lead to cirrhosis and liver failure.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A chronic, transmural inflammation that can affect any location along the gastrointestinal tract.

Concepts.definition: A gastrointestinal disorder characterized by chronic inflammation involving all layers of the intestinal wall, noncaseating granulomas affecting the intestinal wall and regional lymph nodes, and transmural fibrosis. Crohn disease most commonly involves the terminal ileum; the colon is the second most common site of involvement.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 1/25/23 added alt name for ticket number CADSR0001948 for CCTG cjl.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A genetic disorder characterized by decreased alpha-1 antitrypsin activity in the lungs and blood and deposition of alpha-1 antitrypsin protein in the hepatocytes. These abnormalities result from defective production of alpha-1 antitrypsin and lead to the development of emphysema, cirrhosis, and liver failure.

Concepts.definition: A genetic disorder characterized by decreased alpha-1 antitrypsin activity in the lungs and blood and deposition of alpha-1 antitrypsin protein in the hepatocytes. These abnormalities result from defective production of alpha-1 antitrypsin and lead to the development of emphysema, cirrhosis, and liver failure.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A term referring to fatty replacement of the hepatic parenchyma which is not related to alcohol use.

Concepts.definition: A term referring to fatty replacement of the hepatic parenchyma which is not related to alcohol use.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An inherited metabolic disorder characterized by iron accumulation in the tissues.

Concepts.definition: An inherited metabolic disorder characterized by iron accumulation in the tissues.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An RNA virus, causes non-A and non-B Hepatitis and liver cancer

Concepts.definition: A viral infection caused by the hepatitis C virus.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A viral hepatitis caused by the Hepatitis B virus.

Concepts.definition: A viral infection caused by the hepatitis B virus.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The intoxicating beverage, ethanol.: The bodily process of taking in and using up something, especially the eating or drinking of something.

Concepts.definition: A volatile liquid prepared by fermentation of certain carbohydrates. Alcohol acts as a central nervous system (CNS) depressant, a diuretic, and a disinfectant. Although the exact mechanism of CNS depression is unknown, alcohol may act by inhibiting the opening of calcium channels, mediated by the binding of the inhibitory neurotransmitter gamma-amino butyric acid (GABA) to GABA-A receptors, or through inhibitory actions at N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA)-type glutamate receptors. Alcohol inhibits the production of antidiuretic hormone, thereby producing diuresis that may lead to dehydration. This agent kills organisms by denaturing their proteins.
The bodily process of taking in and using up something, especially the eating or drinking of something.

PermissibleValues.value: No History of Primary Risk Factors

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.

Concepts.definition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Exposure to thorotrast, which contains particles of the radioactive compound thorium dioxide, as a radiocontrast agent.  It is a carcinogenic compound, linked to the development of bile duct cancer, leukemia, and angiosarcoma.

Concepts.definition: Exposure to thorotrast, which contains particles of the radioactive compound thorium dioxide, as a radiocontrast agent. It is a carcinogenic compound, linked to the development of bile duct cancer, leukemia, and angiosarcoma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An infection caused by the parasite Opisthorchis viverrini. It results from the ingestion of raw or undercooked food. The clinical features vary from mild to severe and include gastrointestinal symptoms, anorexia, weight loss, hepatomegaly, and cholangitis. Patients are at an increased risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma.

Concepts.definition: An infection caused by the parasite Opisthorchis viverrini. It results from the ingestion of raw or undercooked food. The clinical features vary from mild to severe and include gastrointestinal symptoms, anorexia, weight loss, hepatomegaly, and cholangitis. Patients are at an increased risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An inflammatory bowel disease involving the mucosal surface of the large intestine and rectum. It may present with an acute or slow onset and follows an intermittent or continuous course. Signs and symptoms include abdominal pain, diarrhea, fever, weight loss, and intestinal hemorrhage.

Concepts.definition: An inflammatory bowel disease involving the mucosal surface of the large intestine and rectum. It may present with an acute or slow onset and follows an intermittent or continuous course. Signs and symptoms include abdominal pain, diarrhea, fever, weight loss, and intestinal hemorrhage.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The act of puffing and/or inhaling smoke from a lit cigarette, cigar, or pipe.

Concepts.definition: The act of puffing and/or inhaling smoke from a lit cigarette, cigar, or pipe.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The presence of solitary or multiple stones in the intrahepatic bile ducts.

Concepts.definition: The presence of solitary or multiple stones in the intrahepatic bile ducts.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A rare congenital disorder characterized by cystic dilatation of the intrahepatic bile ducts. It is associated with cholangitis and the formation of stones.

Concepts.definition: A rare congenital disorder characterized by cystic dilatation of the intrahepatic bile ducts. It is associated with cholangitis and the formation of stones.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Cystic dilatation of the hepatic duct or bile duct.

Concepts.definition: Cystic dilatation of the hepatic duct or bile duct.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A metabolic disorder characterized by abnormally high blood sugar levels due to diminished production of insulin or insulin resistance/desensitization.

Concepts.definition: A metabolic disorder characterized by abnormally high blood sugar levels due to diminished production of insulin or insulin resistance/desensitization.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A chronic degenerative disease of the liver characterized by parenchymal nodularity and fibrosis.

Concepts.definition: A disorder characterized by replacement of the liver parenchyma with fibrous tissue and regenerative nodules. It is usually caused by alcoholism, hepatitis B, and hepatitis C. Complications include the development of ascites, esophageal varices, bleeding, and hepatic encephalopathy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A term that refers to the biliary tract structures.: An animal or plant that gets nutrients by living on or in an organism of another species. A complete parasite gets all of its nutrients from the host organism, but a semi-parasite gets only some of its nutrients from the host.

Concepts.definition: A term that refers to the biliary tract structures.
Any organism that has a close, symbiotic relationship with a separate, host organism.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The return of a disease after a period of remission.: Cholangitis that is characterized by pyogenic organisms.

Concepts.definition: The return of a disease after a period of remission.
Cholangitis that is characterized by pyogenic organisms.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Having a high amount of body fat (body mass index [BMI] of 30 or more).

Concepts.definition: Having a high amount of body fat (body mass index [BMI] of 30 or more).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Be specific about something; define clearly.: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Be specific about something; define clearly.
Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A disorder caused by damage to the liver parenchyma due to alcohol consumption. It may present with an acute onset or follow a chronic course, leading to cirrhosis.

Concepts.definition: A disorder caused by damage to the liver parenchyma due to alcohol consumption. It may present with an acute onset or follow a chronic course, leading to cirrhosis.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Top level term which includes Biological Markers, Risk Factors, and Prognostic Factors.
